sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Bahrain is a small island nation in the Persian Gulf, known for its rich history, pearl diving heritage, and modern financial and tourism industries.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Manama is the capital and largest city of Bahrain, serving as its political, cultural, and economic center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Bahraini dinar (BHD).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Arabic, though English is widely spoken in business and education.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include machboos (spiced rice with meat or fish), muhammar (sweet rice with dates), and grilled seafood.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Bahrain is an archipelago of 33 islands in the Persian Gulf, featuring desert terrain, coastal areas, and fertile date palm groves.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Bahraini culture blends Arab traditions with Persian and Indian influences. Music, poetry, and hospitality are central, alongside a legacy of pearl diving.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Bahrain Fort (Qal'at al-Bahrain), the Bahrain National Museum, the Formula 1 Bahrain International Circuit, and traditional souqs.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Bahrain was historically famous for its natural pearls, considered among the finest in the world.

history.event: The Dilmun civilization flourished in Bahrain, serving as a major trade hub between Mesopotamia and the Indus Valley.
Bahrain came under the influence of the Babylonian and later Persian empires.
Islam spread to Bahrain during the lifetime of Prophet Muhammad, becoming the dominant religion.
The Portuguese occupied Bahrain, controlling trade routes in the Persian Gulf.
The Safavid Persians expelled the Portuguese and ruled Bahrain for nearly two centuries.
The Al Khalifa family took control of Bahrain, establishing a dynasty that continues to rule today.
Bahrain signed a treaty with Britain, becoming a British protectorate while retaining internal autonomy.
Oil was discovered in Bahrain, making it the first Gulf state to exploit petroleum resources.
Bahrain declared independence from Britain and joined the United Nations and Arab League.
Bahrain became a constitutional monarchy under King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa.
Protests erupted during the Arab Spring, leading to political unrest and reforms.
